factoid: The speaker toasted the health of lovely women, Peterkin, and their lovers.
Pierre drank out of his glass.
Pierre did not look at Dólokhov.
Pierre did not answer Dólokhov.
The footman was distributing leaflets with Kutúzov’s cantata.
The footman laid a leaflet before Pierre.
Pierre was one of the principal guests.
Pierre was about to take the leaflet.
Dólokhov leaned across.
Dólokhov snatched the leaflet from Pierre’s hand.
Dólokhov began reading the leaflet.
Pierre looked at Dólokhov.
Pierre’s eyes dropped.
The terrible thing that had tormented Pierre all dinnertime rose.
The terrible thing took possession of Pierre.
Pierre leaned his whole massive body across the table.
Pierre shouted, “How dare you take it?”
Nesvítski heard the cry.
Nesvítski saw to whom the cry was addressed.
Nesvítski turned in alarm to Bezúkhov.
The neighbor on Nesvítski’s right turned in alarm to Bezúkhov.
Nesvítski whispered, “Don’t! Don’t! What are you about?”
The neighbor whispered, “Don’t! Don’t! What are you about?”
Dólokhov looked at Pierre with clear, mirthful, cruel eyes.
Dólokhov smiled.
Dólokhov’s smile seemed to say, “Ah! This is what I like!”
Dólokhov said distinctly, “You shan’t have it!”
Pierre snatched the copy.
Pierre was pale.
Pierre had quivering lips.
Pierre said, “You…! you… scoundrel! I challenge you!”
Pierre pushed back his chair.
Pierre rose from the table.
Pierre felt that the question of his wife’s guilt was finally answered in the affirmative.
Pierre hated his wife.
Pierre was forever sundered from his wife.
Denísov requested that Rostóv take no part in the matter.
Rostóv agreed to be Dólokhov’s second.
Rostóv discussed the arrangements for the duel with Nesvítski.
Rostóv discussed the arrangements for the duel with Bezúkhov.
Rostóv’s discussion occurred after dinner.
Pierre went home.
Rostóv stayed at the club till late.
Dólokhov stayed at the club till late.
Denísov stayed at the club till late.
Rostóv, Dólokhov, and Denísov listened to gypsies and other singers.
Dólokhov said, “Well then, till tomorrow at Sokólniki.”
Dólokhov took leave of Rostóv in the club porch.
Rostóv asked Dólokhov, “And do you feel quite calm?”
Dólokhov paused.
Dólokhov told the whole secret of dueling in two words.
Dólokhov said, “If you are going to fight a duel, and you make a will and write affectionate letters to your parents, and if you think you may be killed, you are a fool and are lost for certain.”
Dólokhov said, “But go with the firm intention of killing your man as quickly and surely as possible, and then all will be right.”
Dólokhov said, “As our bear huntsman at Kostromá used to tell me.”
Dólokhov quoted, “‘Everyone fears a bear,’ he says, ‘but when you see one your fear’s all gone, and your only thought is not to let him get away!’”
Dólokhov said, “And that’s how it is with me.”
Dólokhov said, “À demain, mon cher.”
The speaker said, “Till tomorrow, my dear fellow.”
The next day at eight in the morning, Pierre and Nesvítski drove to the Sokólniki forest.
Pierre and Nesvítski found Dólokhov, Denísov, and Rostóv already there.
Pierre had the air of a man preoccupied with considerations that had no connection with the matter in hand.
Pierre’s haggard face was yellow.
Pierre had not slept that night.
Pierre looked about distractedly.
Pierre screwed up his eyes as if dazzled by the sun.
Pierre was entirely absorbed by his wife’s guilt.
Pierre was entirely absorbed by the guiltlessness of Dólokhov.
Pierre had no doubt about his wife’s guilt after his sleepless night.
Dólokhov had no reason to preserve the honor of a man who was nothing to him.
Pierre thought, “I should perhaps have done the same thing in his place.”
Pierre thought, “It’s even certain that I should have done the same.”
Pierre questioned why this duel and this murder.
Pierre considered that he might kill Dólokhov.
Pierre considered that Dólokhov might hit him in the head, elbow, or knee.
Pierre wondered if he could go away from here, run away, and bury himself somewhere.
Pierre would ask, “Will it be long? Are things ready?”
Pierre asked this in a calm and absent-minded way.
The onlookers respected Pierre’s manner.
When all was ready, the sabers stuck in the snow to mark the barriers.
The pistols were loaded.
Nesvítski went up to Pierre.
